question: Question_01_(d)
statement:
\emph{\textbf{Short-Answer Questions.} Put your answer in the box
provided but show your work also. Each question is worth 3 marks, but
not all questions are of equal difficulty. Full marks will be given for
correct answers placed in the box, but at most 1 mark will be given for
incorrect answers. Unless otherwise stated, it is not necessary to
simplify your answers in this question.}

Suppose \emph{f} and \emph{g} are continuous functions such that
\emph{g(3) = 2} and

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 3} (xf(x) + g(x)) = 1.\end{align*} Find \emph{f(3)}.
sols:
Our goal is to find \emph{f(3)}. Since \emph{f(x)} is continuous we know
that $f(3) = \lim_{x \to 3} f(x)$ and thus finding \emph{f(3)} amounts
to finding the limit.

Using the limit laws we have

\begin{align*}1 = \lim_{x \to 3} (xf(x) + g(x)) = \lim_{x \to 3} x \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) + \lim_{x \to 3} g(x).\end{align*}
Using that both functions \emph{x} and \emph{g(x)} are continuous, we
have that

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 3} x = 3\end{align*} and

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 3} g(x) = g(3) = 2.\end{align*} Plugin this into the above equality,
we find

\begin{align*}1 = 3 \lim_{x \to 3} f(x) + 2\end{align*} and hence

\begin{align*}\lim_{x \to 3} f(x) = - \frac{1}{3} .\end{align*}

By the first remark above we have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle f(3) =  - \frac{1}{3}.\end{align*}
hints: What limit laws can you use to separate the limit?
